fields.Title: Idaho Bird Observatory Fall Migration Monitoring of Raptors and Songbirds, Boise Ridge, Idaho: 2011 Annual Report
fields.Description/Abstract:
The Idaho Bird Observatory (IBO) is a Boise State University Academic Research Program.
The IBO’s mission is to contribute to the conservation of Western migratory landbirds through
cooperative research and public education. The IBO’s longest-running research and education
effort is a fall migration project located on the Boise Ridge. The Boise Ridge is one of only a
few known sites in the western U.S. where great numbers of diurnal raptors, songbirds, and
forest owls concentrate during fall migration. This site presents a unique opportunity to study
the migration biology of many different kinds of birds in one locality. Studies have identified
important habitats used by migrants, breeding and wintering areas, and have contributed to longterm
population monitoring. The site also offers a unique opportunity for wildlife viewing.
Hundreds of visitors each year travel to IBO research sites to view songbirds, raptors, and forest
owls. We have established a community volunteer program to provide the public with
opportunities to participate in IBO programs. All standardized migration monitoring projects
continued during fall 2011.
We counted migrating raptors on 65 days during 2011, observing for a total of 445 hours. We
counted a total of 5,985 migrant raptors for a passage rate of 13.5 raptors per hour, slightly above
the 18-year average of 13.02 raptors per hour. Counts of Sharp-shinned Hawks, Turkey Vultures,
Merlins, Broad-winged Hawks, and Peregrine Falcons were all well above long-term averages.
However, counts of Cooper’s Hawks, Red-tailed Hawks, Northern Harriers, and Prairie Falcons
were below long-term averages. Overall, total counts of migrant raptors during 2011 were only
0.1% below the long-term average based on 18 years of standardized monitoring at Lucky Peak.
We banded a total of 1,023 diurnal raptors in 2011 at two banding stations during 112 stationdays
of operation, for a capture rate of 9.1 raptors per station-day. The most commonly-banded
raptors were Sharp-shinned Hawks, Cooper's Hawks, American Kestrels, Merlins, Northern
Goshawks, and Red-tailed Hawks. To date, we have received a total of 136 band encounters
from raptors banded on the Boise Ridge. Many banded raptors have been encountered from the
Boise area, but other recoveries have come from western Mexico, Baja California, southern
California, Washington, and British Columbia. Three general patterns are evident from studying
Idaho Bird Observatory raptor band encounters: 1) mid-winter recoveries of Sharp-shinned and
Cooper’s Hawks come from western Mexico in the states of Sonora, Sinaloa, Colima, and farther
south; 2) mid-winter recoveries of Red-tailed Hawks come from California’s Central Valley; and
3) spring and summer recoveries of Sharp-shinned and Cooper’s Hawks come from as far north
as central British Columbia.
In songbird mist nets, we captured a total of 5,196 birds of 52 species during 4,364.5 mist-net
hours. This capture rate (1.191 birds per mist-net hour) is slightly lower than the long-term
average. The ten most commonly-captured species were Yellow-rumped Warbler, RubyCrowned
Kinglet, Nashville Warbler, White-crowned Sparrow, MacGillivray’s Warbler, Dusky
Flycatcher, Yellow Warbler, Chipping Sparrow, Spotted Towhee, and Western Tanager, marking
the first season in which Dark-eyed Junco was not among the ten most abundant species. We
had record-high captures for five species in 2011, including Nashville Warbler, Tennessee
Warbler, Yellow-rumped Warbler, American Redstart, and Song Sparrow. 
During fall 2011 we mist netted for forest owls on 59 nights for a total of 1,584 station-hours. A
total of 595 owls were banded, including one Northern Pygmy-Owl, 43 Flammulated Owls and
551 Northern Saw-whet Owls.
A record 46 groups, including over 850 participants, scheduled visits to Lucky Peak during 2011.
Groups included Golden Eagle Audubon Society, Idaho Department of Fish and Game Project
Wild, Foothills School, Anser Charter School, Southwest Idaho Birders Association, and several
local Scouting and home school groups. Timely local articles in Treasure Valley Family
Magazine and The Idaho Statesman in August and early September resulted in over 1,000
additional public visitors (not associated with organized groups) to the Lucky Peak research site.
In 2011, 41 volunteers contributed 953 days totaling approximately 8,190 hours of volunteer
service to assist with IBO projects. The estimated cash value of this volunteer time and
volunteer vehicle contributions was $217,686.29.
Ongoing graduate research projects associated with IBO during fall 2011 included a study of
stress response in migrant raptors, a study of blood parasites in migrant raptors, and a study of
observer bias and detectability of raptors associated with hawk migration counts.
